title: C digital performance and film

venue.name: C ARTS | C venues | C place
venue.description: Discover new dimensions at our new hub in the heart of the New Town, with live theatre, music and cabaret, immersive experiences, digital performance and film. Part of the vibrant vivacious variety of C ARTS: a curated programme of international independent work taking place at multiple city-centre locations, and online, in our 31st year at the Fringe. It’s a festival all of its own. Make sure you see it all.
venue.disabled_description: Limited access to some parts of venue site, Wheelchair accessible toilet, No reserved accessible parking, On street blue badge parking, Assistance dogs welcome in all areas. Entrance to venue is down flight of stairs in external courtyard, performance spaces down a further half flight of stairs from foyer. Level access to cellar and immersion spaces from Dublin Street Lane South by advance arrangement (phone 0131 581 5552)
venue.cafe_description: Licensed café-bars offering teas and coffees, wine and cocktails, bar snacks and full meals until late. Open air terrace bar and restaurant. Festival bar open late, offering live music, cabaret performances, festival events and showcases.

description: Hand-picked shows from our digital performance programme and highlights from our critically acclaimed short film programme. Pop in for a quirky short; linger longer for a moving moment. Features curated work from UK, Europe, Americas, Asia, worldwide. Destination for discerning digital and film audiences. Winner, LiveWire Innovation and Excellence Award for Digital Arts Programme of the Year. ‘Both weird and wondrous’ (ThreeWeeks). ‘Exceptional films’ (BroadwayBaby.com). ‘Delightful... perfect’ (TheWeeReview.com). 'A much-needed pocket of escapism’ (ThreeWeeks). ‘Spectacular’ (Scotsman). Programme runs continuously. Screenings can be any length (typically 30min-1hr). Some screenings at other times. See website for listings.

description: Hand-picked work for children and families from our award-winning digital performance and our critically acclaimed short film programme. Storytelling, multimedia theatre, physical theatre, music, short films and more… Features curated work from independent artists from UK, Europe and further afield. Winner of the LiveWire Innovation and Excellence Award for Digital Arts Programme of the Year. ‘Both weird and wondrous’ (ThreeWeeks). ‘Exceptional films’ (BroadwayBaby.com). ‘Delightful... perfect’ (TheWeeReview.com). A much-needed pocket of escapism’ (ThreeWeeks). ‘Spectacular’ (Scotsman). Programme runs continuously. Screenings can be any length (typically 30min-1hr). Some screenings at other times. See website for listings.

title: A Scandal From Bohemia

venue.name: C ARTS | C venues | C cubed
venue.description: Unleash your imagination at our unique sixteenth-century Royal Mile venue. Captivating children’s shows. Spellbinding storytelling. Powerful physical performance. Dazzling dance. Masterful music. Energetic ensemble theatre. Part of the vibrant vivacious variety of C ARTS: a curated programme of international independent work taking place at multiple city-centre locations, and online, in our 31st year at the Fringe. It’s a festival all of its own. Make sure you see it all.
venue.address: Celtic Lodge, Brodie's Close, Lawnmarket, Royal Mile
venue.disabled_description: There are 25 steps up into this venue. One full flight of stairs and one quarter-flight of stairs up from street level, approx 800mm wide at narrowest. For accessibility information and assisted bookings and to request assistance at the venue in advance, please call the C venues accessline on 0131 581 5552, or email the access team at access@cvenues.com. Limited access to some parts of venue site, No wheelchair accessible toilet, No reserved accessible parking, On street blue badge parking, Assistance dogs welcome in all areas. Access Brodie's Close through archway at 304 Lawnmarket. From courtyard, café to right, venue entrance and toilets to left, on ground floor (up one step). Access to box office, bar, and performance space up one flight of stairs to first floor (no lift)
venue.cafe_description: Licensed venue bar open all day until late. Deacon's House Café open during the day and early evening.

warnings:
Violent Themes, There are attempts at violence which are thwarted. The front rows of the audience will be asked to stand, empty pockets, will be searched under their seats, etc.
Audience participation, Contains distressing themes, Scenes of violence
description: Thirty years after A Scandal in Bohemia, Sherlock Holmes must once again confront The Woman. The only opponent to have ever bested Holmes, Irene Adler Norton, is once again his prime suspect. The Crown Jewels of the House of Bohemia have been stolen, in Edinburgh, where Irene now resides. Coincidence? Specifically, the jewels she wears in the photo with Prince Wilhelm von Ormstein, now King Wilhelm. The fate of Bohemia and all of Europe rests on the recovery of the jewels and time is running out…

title: 7 Seventeen-Year-Olds in a Screwed-Up World

venue.name: C ARTS | C venues | C cubed
venue.description: Unleash your imagination at our unique sixteenth-century Royal Mile venue. Captivating children’s shows. Spellbinding storytelling. Powerful physical performance. Dazzling dance. Masterful music. Energetic ensemble theatre. Part of the vibrant vivacious variety of C ARTS: a curated programme of international independent work taking place at multiple city-centre locations, and online, in our 31st year at the Fringe. description: Seven teenagers. Waiting. Dancing. Hoping. Tim Coker’s brand-new absurdist comedy takes a sharp, satirical look at the modern world. A play about teenagers, which also concerns itself with all the really serious stuff like isolation, racism, impending nuclear annihilation, refugeeism, nail salons and all the other gloomy stuff that’s going on. And after all that, the only thing left is to dance. ‘It is always reassuring to see a student-age company wittily trashing the junk culture fed to them’ **** (Times). ‘Fill the stage with wonder and worry’ **** (BritishTheatreGuide.com).
artist: Square Pegs – Macready Theatre Young Actors' Company

title: Ben Clover: Best Newcomer

venue.name: C ARTS | C venues | C piccolo
venue.description: Catch up with culture at Edinburgh Press Club, an intimate café-cabaret space of stories on Cockburn Street. Scintillating spoken word. Veracious verbatim theatre. Cutting-edge comedic talent. Part of the vibrant vivacious variety of C ARTS: a curated programme of international independent work taking place at multiple city-centre locations, and online, in our 31st year at the Fringe. It’s a festival all of its own. Make sure you see it all.
venue.disabled_description: Limited access to some parts of venue site, No wheelchair accessible toilet, No reserved accessible parking, On street blue badge parking. Cockburn Street links the High Street (Royal Mile) and North Bridge and South Bridge, in the Old Town, with Market Street and Waverley Bridge, and provides mostly level but fairly steeply sloping access between the New Town to the higher level streets of the Old Town
venue.cafe_description: Licensed café-bar service to performance space, serving drinks, light food and snacks before and during shows, and cafe items for takeaway until late.

description: Veteran stand-up comic Ben Clover returns with his seventh show: Best Newcomer. Ben has many successful Fringe runs under his belt, but this is his first in 2022. This year the award-winning comedian tackles the big themes as well as sweating the small stuff. ‘A delight… Inventive and savvy’ (Chortle.co.uk). ‘Comedy gold’ (Bruce Dessau, Evening Standard). ‘A magnificent performance’ (NottsComedyReview.wordpress.com).

title: Blindingly Obvious

venue.name: C ARTS | C venues | C cubed
venue.description: Unleash your imagination at our unique sixteenth-century Royal Mile venue. Captivating children’s shows. Spellbinding storytelling. Powerful physical performance. Dazzling dance. Masterful music. Energetic ensemble theatre. Part of the vibrant vivacious variety of C ARTS: a curated programme of international independent work taking place at multiple city-centre locations, and online, in our 31st year at the Fringe. description: Funny, fast and friendly, Richard brings his unique blend of anecdotes from his unusual life and charming off-the-cuff audience interactions back to the Fringe for another run of high-energy hilarity. Generally clean, always funny, Richard prefers quick and clever wordplay over quick and easy vulgarity. An hour with Britain’s funniest, friendliest blind theoretical physicist turned award-winning broadcast journalist and stand-up comedian is never dull, especially as he promises to keep the maths jokes to a minimum. ‘Blindingly Obvious is blindingly funny’ ***** (Derek Awards 2019).

title: Finding Magic

venue.name: C ARTS | C venues | C cubed
venue.description: Unleash your imagination at our unique sixteenth-century Royal Mile venue. Captivating children’s shows. Spellbinding storytelling. Powerful physical performance. Dazzling dance. Masterful music. Energetic ensemble theatre. Part of the vibrant vivacious variety of C ARTS: a curated programme of international independent work taking place at multiple city-centre locations, and online, in our 31st year at the Fringe. description: Do you believe in magic? Bev does, but after the death of her son Jess she thought she’d never find her magic again. This remarkably uplifting true story of personal survival and triumph shows how she survived her grief and found new hope. Beverley uses storytelling, film, clowning and magic to introduce and demonstrate her new reality of unpredictable triggers, clichés and flashbacks. The audience are invited to share the new-found surreal humour she deploys to find peace after bereavement. Equal parts moving and magical, Finding Magic is a captivating story of loss, longing, love, laughter and solace.

title: Doom and Glitter: A Tribute To Tom Waits

venue.name: C ARTS | C venues | C place
venue.description: Discover new dimensions at our new hub in the heart of the New Town, with live theatre, music and cabaret, immersive experiences, digital performance and film. Part of the vibrant vivacious variety of C ARTS: a curated programme of international independent work taking place at multiple city-centre locations, and online, in our 31st year at the Fringe. Mature Themes; Loud Sounds; Loud Music, Moderate references to sex, drug and alcohol use
Audience participation, Strong language/swearing
description: In this laid-back cabaret filled with vocal impersonations, live singing and bluesy banter, drag king Mr Brake Down pays tribute to the wit and wonderment of the iconic Tom Waits. Gloriously odd and experimental, the show takes audiences on a musical journey through some of Waits' seminal works, whilst Brake expounds on just how much a drag king from South Wales might have in common with the California-born performer. Expect to be bemused in a highly enjoyable fashion by a show that must be seen to be believed!

title: Mr Brake Down: The Headmaster Will See You Now

venue.name: C ARTS | C venues | C place
venue.description: Discover new dimensions at our new hub in the heart of the New Town, with live theatre, music and cabaret, immersive experiences, digital performance and film. description: A special school assembly harking back to the grand old days of the bawdy British boarding school, hosted by drag king and self-proclaimed "Head" Master Mr Brake Down. It's a right carry-on in this St Trinian-esque show as you, the student body, experience the academy announcements, receive a highly stimulating motivational speech from the Head, and hear parables, hymns and storytime as you've never heard them before. This cheeky character comedy show offers drag, debauchery and a dry wit that's sure to suit fans of classic British humour.

title: Pulse

venue.name: C ARTS | C venues | C place
venue.description: Discover new dimensions at our new hub in the heart of the New Town, with live theatre, music and cabaret, immersive experiences, digital performance and film. Mature Themes
Contains distressing themes, Strong language/swearing
description: Exploring the intricacies of family dynamics, Pulse, a new short play, invites the audience into the parent/child experience we’ve all found ourselves in. Daughter Samara reminisces on her relationship with her brass mother Elinor. Vignettes from Samaras growing up set the scene for a dysfunctional, but happy family. When Samara decides to move away with her fiance, conflict arises, and the bond with her mother is put to the test. Written by Elise Marra, writer of Frankie! The Musical, Pulse creates dynamic and comedic characters to tackle serious undertones.

title: Miss Magics

venue.name: C ARTS | C venues | C place
venue.description: Discover new dimensions at our new hub in the heart of the New Town, with live theatre, music and cabaret, immersive experiences, digital performance and film. Part of the vibrant vivacious variety of C ARTS: a curated programme of international independent work taking place at multiple city-centre locations, and online, in our 31st year at the Fringe. Mature Themes; Sexual Themes; Partial Nudity; Loud Music, Mentions of alcoholism and depression
Scenes of a sexual nature, Strong language/swearing
description: Do you believe in magic? Boo and Bunny are best friends. One is an award-winning figure-skater, the other has an award-winning selection of sex toys. They both have a problem: life has started to become grey, the glitter has started to fade… blame your mid-20s! A play that reminds us of the magic from our childhoods, and why we do the things we do in the first place. Told through female perspectives, struggling with self-worth, sexuality, dreams, family and ultimately growing up. A play about love, in all of its forms. A fresh and playful celebration of womanhood.

title: The Life of Riley

venue.name: C ARTS | C venues | C place
venue.description: Discover new dimensions at our new hub in the heart of the New Town, with live theatre, music and cabaret, immersive experiences, digital performance and film. Part of the vibrant vivacious variety of C ARTS: a curated programme of international independent work taking place at multiple city-centre locations, and online, in our 31st year at the Fringe. description: A series of unfortunate events led Riley to realise that there is no place for him in society. He becomes a recluse and a hikikomori, choosing a minimalist lifestyle in a cave. Join him as he explains the events that caused him to make this unusual life-choice. Follow Riley’s life from teen to young adult, as he tries to find himself.

title: Pitchcraft: The Pitch Is Back!

venue.name: St Cuthbert's Church
venue.description: The historic Parish Church of St Cuthbert's sits at the very heart of Edinburgh, on Lothian Road near the junction with Princes Street (opposite the Caledonian Hotel), adjacent to public transport and Castle Terrace car park. It has two superb performance spaces and fine acoustics.
venue.disabled_description: Level access on ground floor. Lift access to Lindisfarne Room. No wheelchair access to gallery. Limited access to some parts of venue site, Wheelchair accessible toilet, Reserved accessible parking, No on street blue badge parking, Assistance dogs welcome in all areas. No wheelchair access to gallery. Level access on ground floor. Lift access to Lindisfarne. Vehicular access is via churchyard entrance on King's Stables Road. Limited parking
venue.cafe_description: We can provide teas/coffees, biscuits and crisps for an additional charge.

description: Returning to the Fringe after sell-out shows in 2016, 2017 and 2018, Pitchcraft are the Edinburgh choir with a difference. Expect uniquely crafted acapella arrangements, each with its own twist, delivered with humour and passion. 'Pitchcraft's energy, emotions and sense of fun are yours. You'll feel it all. If you see one choir this year, this is it' (BroadwayBaby.com).

title: Iain Dale: All Talk with Nicola Sturgeon

venue.name: Pleasance at EICC
venue.description: Join us in the heart of Edinburgh's West End for theatre, comedy, music and family shows. The best of the Fringe awaits in the city’s most luxurious venue, where brilliant bars and cafés join a stellar line up of world renowned artists.
venue.disabled_description: All performance spaces are accessible. Customers with access requirements are encouraged to contact the venue in advance and to make themselves known to a member of the team upon arrival to access lifts. A full accessibility guide can be found at www.pleasance.co.uk. Full venue site is accessible, Wheelchair accessible toilet, No reserved accessible parking, On street blue badge parking, Assistance dogs welcome in all areas. The EICC’s main entrance has an automated sliding doors which are operated by a push button from the outside and by sensor from the inside. During an event these doors are manned with security who can offer assistance if required
venue.cafe_description: A bar service is available for all shows in our performance spaces.

description: Award-winning LBC presenter brings his acclaimed, incisive insight on current affairs back to the Fringe with an in-depth interview featuring audience questions. Today's special guest is Nicola Sturgeon MSP, First Minister of Scotland and Leader of the Scottish National Party, who made her Fringe debut with Iain Dale at his 2019 All Talk season. 'The indefatigable Iain Dale always cuts to the nub of politics' (Adam Boulton). 'There are very few commentators and broadcasters with an instinctive feel for real politics. Iain Dale does, which makes him endlessly listenable-to and peerless' (Andrew Marr).
artist: James Seabright in association with Northbank Speakers

title: How to Record the Greatest Album of All Time

venue.name: Just the Tonic at The Mash House
venue.description: Fringe Venue number 288
venue.disabled_description: Limited access to some parts of venue site, No wheelchair accessible toilet, No reserved accessible parking, No on street blue badge parking, Assistance dogs welcome in all areas. Hidden just off Cowgate on the stairway joining Cowgate and Guthrie Street

description: Comedian Tom GK has decided to record the greatest album of all time and he has just 50 minutes to prove he's up to the job. This hilarious new show from the almost-deaf former music critic explores his love of music, taking a chance and using those pandemic days, er, very wisely indeed. The odds might be stacked against him but this joke-filled hour is set to be a must-see performance for any music lover. 'Will leave you singing for joy!' **** (FourthWallMedia.wordpress.com). 'A deft way with storytelling' (TheWest.com.au).

title: Copper, Ash and Fire

venue.name: Leith Community Pottery
venue.description: This is a working pottery, producing high temperature, reduction-fired stoneware. It is a fully equipped, professional studio, housing one of the only working reduction kilns in Edinburgh and visitors to the exhibition will be able to view the making processes in progress on the day of their visit.
venue.disabled_description: Limited access to some parts of venue site, No wheelchair accessible toilet, No reserved accessible parking

description: Copper, Ash and Fire. An exhibition of new, high-fired stoneware by Andy Lang, The Potter of Leith, using mainly wood, ash and copper-based glazes, showcasing the famously elusive copper reds possible only in reduction firing. An artisan of over 40 years experience, Andy's work is wheel thrown and both functional and decorative. Small 2D and 3D pieces by local guest artists and makers will be on show alongside the display of contemporary ceramics. It will also be possible to visit the adjacent workshop of Leith Community Pottery to observe techniques, practices and works in progress.

title: Fat Chance

venue.name: Pleasance Dome
venue.description: The Pleasance Dome is at the very centre of the now famous Bristo Square, featuring the very best comedy and theatre in five venues all under one roof. With great bars and cafes, come soak up the legendary Pleasance atmosphere throughout the day and stay for the fun late in to the night.
venue.disabled_description: All performance spaces are accessible. A full accessibility guide can be found at www.pleasance.co.uk. Full venue site is accessible, Wheelchair accessible toilet, No reserved accessible parking, No on street blue badge parking, Assistance dogs welcome in all areas. A full accessibility guide can be found at www.pleasance.co.uk. Customers with access requirements are encouraged to contact the venue in advance and to make themselves known to a member of the team upon arrival to access lifts
venue.cafe_description: Two bars, a coffee shop and large cafe - all with undercover seating. Food served all day.

performance_space.name: JackDome
performance_space.age_limit: Under 16s accompanied by an adult may be on the premises until 00:00. 16-17 year olds until 01:00. Licensing restrictions may be subject to change.

warnings:
Please note, this show contains strong language and adult themes including disordered eating (also known as diet culture) and references to childhood abuse.
Audience participation, Contains distressing themes, Strong language/swearing, More information
description: Written and performed by Rachel Stockdale. Meet Rachel – a Northern, 20-something actress whose funny, celebratory and politically powerful one-woman play explores her true-life experience of weight gain from size 8 to 18. From audition nerves and throwaway comments to literally breaking a leg, this unconventional play is for: Anyone who's put on or lost weight; Anyone who had free school meals; Anyone who's tried to have it all.

title: Kirsten Coelho | Uncertain Cadence

venue.name: The Scottish Gallery
venue.description: Established in South St. David Street, Edinburgh by Aitken Dott in 1842 as Gilders, Framers, and Artists' Colourmen, the firm, as it does today, also exhibited and sold work by the leading Scottish artists of the day. We have a monthly programme of contemporary and historical exhibitions and we specialise in national and international applied arts. This year the Scottish Gallery is celebrating their 180th Anniversary.
venue.disabled_description: Limited access to some parts of venue site, No wheelchair accessible toilet, No reserved accessible parking, On street blue badge parking, Assistance dogs welcome in all areas. Please note that the gallery spaces are only accessed by a flight of stairs upon entering The Gallery

description: Australian ceramicist Kirsten Coelho presents her first solo exhibition, Uncertain Cadence, with The Scottish Gallery. Kirsten Coelho works in porcelain, producing reduction-fired works that attempt to fuse the formal and the abstract. More recently, her work has been influenced by 19th and early 20th-century enamel wares and and the abstract-surface possibilities these objects can show as they begin to age. ‘I have always felt drawn to the abstract in art – the potential for understanding through an ambiguous and imperceptible type of knowing' (Kirsten Coelho).

title: Duncan Shanks | Riverbank – Landscape of Sorrow and Hope

venue.name: The Scottish Gallery
venue.description: Established in South St. David Street, Edinburgh by Aitken Dott in 1842 as Gilders, Framers, and Artists' Colourmen, the firm, as it does today, also exhibited and sold work by the leading Scottish artists of the day. We have a monthly programme of contemporary and historical exhibitions and we specialise in national and international applied arts. This year the Scottish Gallery is celebrating their 180th Anniversary.
venue.disabled_description: Limited access to some parts of venue site, No wheelchair accessible toilet, No reserved accessible parking, On street blue badge parking, Assistance dogs welcome in all areas. Please note that the gallery spaces are only accessed by a flight of stairs upon entering The Gallery

description: Duncan Shanks finds his subject in his riverside garden in the Clyde Valley, painting the changing seasons with an emotional engagement that chronicles the constant cycle of loss and renewal. The artist writes: 'My subject is nature and the transience of nature. To find that which endures in that which fades. To paint not just the objects, not just the tree, the flower, the cloud and the bird, but how they move and change in time.'

title: Waiting for Hamlet

venue.name: theSpaceTriplex
venue.description: Next door to theSpace @ Surgeons Hall, theSpaceTriplex makes up part of our fabulously smart destination hub of 10 performance spaces located right at the heart of the modern Fringe and offers an unmissable platform of diverse live performance. Music, dance, theatre, physical theatre, a capella, opera, comedy and cabaret. A vibrant programme of performance, all under one roof in the most spectacular space in town.
venue.disabled_description: Full venue site is accessible, Wheelchair accessible toilet, No reserved accessible parking, On street blue badge parking, Assistance dogs welcome in all areas. One step up from a flat pavement, near to the corner of Hill Square and Nicholson Street. The venue has 3 floors all easily accessible via a platform lift

description: The story Shakespeare never told. Stuck in purgatory with his old fool, Yorick, a murdered king plots revenge on his brother. He needs the help of his son, Hamlet, to win back his crown and his wife. What could possibly go wrong? Being dead doesn’t mean you have to take it lying down, but you can’t put right what’s rightly written wrong. Winner of the Kenneth Branagh New Writing Award, this comedy about a tragedy sees Yorick try to stop the King making the biggest mistake of his afterlife. ‘A Masterclass’ ***** (UpstagedManchester.com). 'A joy' **** (BroadwayBaby.com).

title: Dolly Diamond's Bosom Buddies

venue.name: House of Oz
venue.description: For one year only, an all-Australian showcase for all forms of creative and artistic expression, via the UK / Australia Season of Culture.  Experience vibrant Aussie performances, art, culture and gourmet tucker. Catch a show at The Great Indoors, or Outback , get your cosplay on for a cult Aussie movie, try a Lamington or Sausage Sizzle, host a meeting with the best flat white... or simply come dancing!
venue.disabled_description: Limited access to some parts of venue site, Wheelchair accessible toilet, No reserved accessible parking, No on street blue badge parking, Assistance dogs welcome in all areas

description: Award-winning, sharp-tongued cabaret diva Dolly Diamond returns to Edinburgh for only a limited number of nights of inimitable Dolly-style cabaret at The House Of Oz – with some sugar, spice and only a little bit of nice. Brilliantly accompanied by her long-suffering musical director, Cameron Thomas, Ms Diamond hits the ground running with this fabulous show and invites some of her fabulous friends to perform alongside her. Dolly Diamond's Bosom Buddies is not only the show Edinburgh needs right now, it's the show Edinburgh deserves.

title: A Political Breakfast

venue.name: PBH's Free Fringe @ Natural Food Kafe
venue.description: Cafe and health food store offering freshly prepared vegetarian, vegan, gluten-free, Scottish food and drink on the menu from 9am daily. During the Fringe we host a selection of PBH Free Fringe shows in our basement function room. No age restrictions.
venue.disabled_description: Limited access to some parts of venue site. Level access into the shop. The performance space is down a flight of stairs

description: A Political Breakfast is on, and over, absurdly early. It serves up fun "solutions" to modern political problem from a panel of up to 4 acts, depending on the alarm clocks working, chaired by Harun Musho'd and Chris O'Neill with involvement from the audience. Have I Got News For You crashes into Question Time! (Breakfast is available from the venue).

title: Harmon Leon in The Jokes Saved My Soul

venue.name: PBH's Free Fringe @ Banshee Labyrinth
venue.description: The Banshee Labyrinth is a teeming pub that is said to be Scotland's most haunted pub. Three performance spaces, three bars, one open from 12.30-05:00. Over 18s only. www.thebansheelabyrinth.com
venue.disabled_description: Limited access to some parts of venue site
venue.cafe_description: Bars serving alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks, teas and coffees, open daily during August from 11:00 to 05:00, Sunday from 12:30.

description: NYC comedian Harmon Leon (VICE) lives a double life. On-Stage Harmon is very confident and shows no fear. Off-Stage Harmon has anxiety ordering a kabob at a takeaway. But the therapy that he has found to feel normal is coming on stage and doing The Jokes. A multimedia nod to Samuel Beckett’s Krapp’s Last Tape and hit at festivals worldwide. 'Leon takes a risk with his comedy and audiences should too' ***** (Advertiser, Adelaide). 'This was the kind of risky performance the Fringe is supposed to be about' (Rip It Up, Australia).

title: See It On Screen Summer 22

venue.name: Brioche Dundas Street
venue.description: A newly-refurbished New Town cafe/bar, offering a bistro menu of locally sourced, freshly prepared brioche rolls, as well as a fully-licensed bar. Neighbouring Clark's Bar offers an authentic pub experience with occasional live music and regular sport on display. Matinee attendees may enjoy the nearby Royal Botanical Gardens, and the extended nightlife of the neighbourhood will please any evening ticket holder.
venue.disabled_description: Limited access to some parts of venue site, Wheelchair accessible toilet, No reserved accessible parking, Assistance dogs welcome in all areas

performance_space.name: The Edinburgh Graffiti Screen, at Brioche

warnings:
Brief flashing blue light in one film.
Strobe lighting, More information
description: Three original short films made in Edinburgh, by new Edinburgh film company See It On Screen. Audience reviews: 'Feel good films from start to finish', 'gorgeous, delicate storytelling' and 'great beauty can come from the things that you find, the things you see, when you really look; this director is a finder and a see-er'. Bonus films will feature during weekend performances. Great food and drinks available at the fully-licenced venue. See It On Screen. Films by anyone, for everyone. Community, alchemy and serendipity.

title: Aural Picnic

venue.name: PBH's Free Fringe @ Banshee Labyrinth
venue.description: The Banshee Labyrinth is a teeming pub that is said to be Scotland's most haunted pub. Three performance spaces, three bars, one open from 12.30-05:00. Over 18s only. www.thebansheelabyrinth.com

venue.cafe_description: Bars serving alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks, teas and coffees, open daily during August from 11:00 to 05:00, Sunday from 12:30.

description: Aural Picnic: Fill your ears with tasty tales. Local lass brings to life contemporary stories with humour and vigour performed in anthropomorphic characters from nature and myth. Stories for grown-ups written by the performer in the style of (sarcastic) fairy tales, reflecting on social situations. Definitely not your granny's fairy tales.
